HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE. MD., OCTOBER 24, 1924

Senior Presidency
Still Undecided
Because of a class by-law
requiring a majority in all
elections, W. C. Calhoun and
W. K. Morrill are deadlocked
for President of the Senior
Class. At the elections of the
class on Wednesday, Calhoun,
although . possessing a large
plurality, did not have enough
votes to satisfy the majority
requirement. A revote will be
taken in the near future.
Other results of the elections were: M. Urner, VicePresident; R. Wienefeld,
Secretary; D. Reese, Treasurer; K. Miller, Sergeant-atArms.

HOPKINS PROFESSOR IS A
MEMBER OF IMPORTANT COMMITTEE
Prof. John H. Gregory, Head of Civil
Engineering Dept., Consulted By
City of Chicago

Dr. Willoughby Attends
Geneva Conference
According to a cable received Monday by a local
newspaper, Dr. W. W. Willoughby, professor in Political Science at the Johns Hopkins University, has arrived
at Geneva, Switzerland, where
he is participating in the.
League of Nations discussion
on the Chinese opium trade.
China has retained Dr. Willoughby as Constitutional Advisor to see that the rights of
that country are not infringed
upon M the league's effort to
break the opium traffic. Dr.
Willoughby has played an important part in the development of the government of
China.

freest discussion of matters of general

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS LETTER, OCTOBER 24, 1924

NMI

ORGANIZATION MEETING
OF A. S. C. E. HELD
Plans for the coming year were
outlined by President William
Kaufholz at the organization meeting of the Hopkins student chapter of the American Society of
Civil Engineers, held last Friday,
October 18. It was announced that
the speaker for the regular meeting
Friday, October 24, will be Mr.
Earl Stimson, chief engineer, maintenance of way, of the Baltimore
and Ohio Railroad. Mr. Stimson,
who is one of the most prominent
engineers in the city, delivered last
year one of the "Engineering Practice" lectures, given annually by
the School of Engineering.
Today's meeting will be followed
by a smoker, as is customary. The
schedule of monthly meetings to be
given this year was not announced
at this meeting but negotiations are
being made with several important
civil engineers to address the future meetings.
Officers of the society expect that
the membership will be practically
doubled this year, as the enrollment in the civil engineering department has increased in a similar ratio. Although freshmen are not
eligible, the enrollment of upperclassmen has reached almost one
PUBLICITY BOARD TO MOVE hundred per cent in the last two
years.

DEBATING COUNCIL PLANS
IMPORTANT CONTESTS
Debating will regain some of its
former prestige at Hopkins if the
Plans for the present season are
carried out. The first step was
taken a week ago, when candidates
Were called for the freshman and
sophomore debating teams. The
zmnual debate between the two lower classes will be held at an Assembly on either December 11 or
12. In January the juniors and
seniors will clash.
Prospects for the varsity debating team are bright; although Gross
is the only regular back from last
year, a successful team should be
built up from members of last
year's class teams and from freshmen who have had experience in
debating.
A very attractive schedule is in
the making. The team will go to
Lexington, Va., to hold a triangular
debate with Washington and Lee
and the University of North Carolina. A trip to the University of
Richmond to hold a _return debate
IS Practically
assured. _In the contest held at Hopkins last year, Rich ni°nd was the victor. Debates with
other college teams are -pending, including- one with the University
of Virginia.

RIFLE TEAM BEGINS RANGE
PRACTICE
Bang! Zip! Bull's-eye!
With this brief introduction the
Rifle Club began range practice
Monday, up in the North attic of
Gilman Hall. According to Lieutenant Sherwood, who is coaching
the club, a great many students
have become interested in sharpshooting this year, and from 9:30
A. M. to 4:00 P. M. every day,
life on the range is just one sharp
report after another. Due to large
membership a schedule ,has been
posted with the names of men assigned to certain periods of practice
during the week.
To add a pinch of ginger to the
daily practicing, contests will be
staged among the club members
themselves in a few weeks. Details
will be announced later.
Exact dates of shooting matches
with other colleges have not yet
been decided upon, but it is said
they will be held some time in December. At that time, the 15 men
making the highest scores the week
before each match will compete
with the opposing team. One hundred is the standard of perfect
marksmanship, each man getting
ten shots at his target and each
bull's-eye counting ten points.
Commenting upon results so far,
Lieutenant Sherwood said: "It is
too early to form any definite idea
as to how many real sharpshooters
are in the making or already made,
but rivalry is very keen and no one
wastes his ammunition. I feel sure
that with its large enrollment and,
incidentally, with its eight brandnew rifles, the club will produce this
year an unusual team."

LOM BARD and SOUTH STREETS
In one of the best exhibitions of
inter-class baseball ever seen at
Hopkins, the juniors vanquished
the freshmen by the score of two
to one. The game which was replete with thrills from the first inning until the fifth, was not decided
until the final out. The remarkabL
part of the game was the extremely low number of errors committed by the two teams. But three
miscues were made by the losers
whereas the winners were credited
with five, a truly small total for an
inter-class game. Even one or two
of these might have been averted
had it not been for the autumn chill.
Goodwin, of the juniors, pitched
excellent ball, striking out eleven
men, and holding the opposition to
six hits. Shulties was the batting
star, getting a triple and a single in
three times up.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE. MD., OCTOBER 24, 1924

Senior Presidency
Still Undecided
Because of a class by-law
requiring a majority in all
elections, W. C. Calhoun and
W. K. Morrill are deadlocked
for President of the Senior
Class. At the elections of the
class on Wednesday, Calhoun,
although . possessing a large
plurality, did not have enough
votes to satisfy the majority
requirement. A revote will be
taken in the near future.
Other results of the elections were: M. Urner, VicePresident; R. Wienefeld,
Secretary; D. Reese, Treasurer; K. Miller, Sergeant-atArms.

HOPKINS PROFESSOR IS A
MEMBER OF IMPORTANT COMMITTEE
Prof. John H. Gregory, Head of Civil
Engineering Dept., Consulted By
City of Chicago

Dr. Willoughby Attends
Geneva Conference
According to a cable received Monday by a local
newspaper, Dr. W. W. Willoughby, professor in Political Science at the Johns Hopkins University, has arrived
at Geneva, Switzerland, where
he is participating in the.
League of Nations discussion
on the Chinese opium trade.
China has retained Dr. Willoughby as Constitutional Advisor to see that the rights of
that country are not infringed
upon M the league's effort to
break the opium traffic. Dr.
Willoughby has played an important part in the development of the government of
China.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS LETTER, OCTOBER 24, 1924

NMI

ORGANIZATION MEETING
OF A. S. C. E. HELD
Plans for the coming year were
outlined by President William
Kaufholz at the organization meeting of the Hopkins student chapter of the American Society of
Civil Engineers, held last Friday,
October 18. It was announced that
the speaker for the regular meeting
Friday, October 24, will be Mr.
Earl Stimson, chief engineer, maintenance of way, of the Baltimore
and Ohio Railroad. Mr. Stimson,
who is one of the most prominent
engineers in the city, delivered last
year one of the "Engineering Practice" lectures, given annually by
the School of Engineering.
Today's meeting will be followed
by a smoker, as is customary. The
schedule of monthly meetings to be
given this year was not announced
at this meeting but negotiations are
being made with several important
civil engineers to address the future meetings.
Officers of the society expect that
the membership will be practically
doubled this year, as the enrollment in the civil engineering department has increased in a similar ratio. Although freshmen are not
eligible, the enrollment of upperclassmen has reached almost one

years.

DEBATING COUNCIL PLANS
IMPORTANT CONTESTS
Debating will regain some of its
former prestige at Hopkins if the
Plans for the present season are
carried out. The first step was
taken a week ago, when candidates
Were called for the freshman and
sophomore debating teams. The
zmnual debate between the two lower classes will be held at an Assembly on either December 11 or
12. In January the juniors and
seniors will clash.
Prospects for the varsity debating team are bright; although Gross
is the only regular back from last
year, a successful team should be
built up from members of last
year's class teams and from freshmen who have had experience in
debating.
A very attractive schedule is in
the making. The team will go to
Lexington, Va., to hold a triangular
debate with Washington and Lee
and the University of North Carolina. A trip to the University of
Richmond to hold a _return debate
IS Practically
assured. _In the contest held at Hopkins last year, Rich ni°nd was the victor. Debates with
other college teams are -pending, including- one with the University
of Virginia.

RIFLE TEAM BEGINS RANGE
PRACTICE
Bang! Zip! Bull's-eye!
With this brief introduction the
Rifle Club began range practice
Monday, up in the North attic of
Gilman Hall. According to Lieutenant Sherwood, who is coaching
the club, a great many students
have become interested in sharpshooting this year, and from 9:30
A. M. to 4:00 P. M. every day,
life on the range is just one sharp
report after another. Due to large
membership a schedule ,has been
posted with the names of men assigned to certain periods of practice
during the week.
To add a pinch of ginger to the
daily practicing, contests will be
staged among the club members
themselves in a few weeks. Details
will be announced later.
Exact dates of shooting matches
with other colleges have not yet
been decided upon, but it is said
they will be held some time in December. At that time, the 15 men
making the highest scores the week
before each match will compete
with the opposing team. One hundred is the standard of perfect
marksmanship, each man getting
ten shots at his target and each
bull's-eye counting ten points.
Commenting upon results so far,
Lieutenant Sherwood said: "It is
too early to form any definite idea
as to how many real sharpshooters
are in the making or already made,
but rivalry is very keen and no one
wastes his ammunition. I feel sure
that with its large enrollment and,
incidentally, with its eight brandnew rifles, the club will produce this
year an unusual team."

LOM BARD and SOUTH STREETS
In one of the best exhibitions of
inter-class baseball ever seen at
Hopkins, the juniors vanquished
the freshmen by the score of two
to one. The game which was replete with thrills from the first inning until the fifth, was not decided
until the final out. The remarkabL
part of the game was the extremely low number of errors committed by the two teams. But three
miscues were made by the losers
whereas the winners were credited
with five, a truly small total for an
inter-class game. Even one or two
of these might have been averted
had it not been for the autumn chill.
Goodwin, of the juniors, pitched
excellent ball, striking out eleven
men, and holding the opposition to
six hits. Shulties was the batting
star, getting a triple and a single in
three times up.
